settings.heading: Fighting for the blue heart of our planet since 1992

settings.text: World Oceans Day has been celebrated every year on June 8 since 1992. On this day, millions of people around the world come together to celebrate our one shared ocean, discuss the most pressing social and environmental issues impacting the ocean (and the people who rely on it to survive), and collaborate on crucial conservation initiatives that will protect and restore it for generations to come.

The ocean is the world’s largest ecosystem and the life support system of our planet. Without the ocean, life as we know it simply would not exist. So no matter how far away you live, even if you’ve never seen it, the ocean touches you with every breath you take and every drop of water you drink. Let’s explore some of the reasons why the ocean deserves to be celebrated and, more importantly, protected.

settings.heading: Many important medicines are made with ingredients from the ocean
settings.subheading: More than 10,000 compounds have been extracted from the ocean to produce medicines that help fight diseases like cancer, heart disease, arthritis, and Alzheimer’s. These compounds are also used in activities like biomedical research and diagnostic testing, which are crucial to understanding, identifying, and treating disease.

settings.heading: More than 3 billion people rely on the ocean for their livelihoods
settings.subheading: Ocean-based industries like fishing and tourism employ millions of people around the world. The blue economy contributes several trillion dollars of goods and services to the global economy every year.

settings.heading: The ocean accounts for about 80% of the world’s biodiversity
settings.subheading: Scientists estimate that there are over 2 million species that inhabit the marine environment and 90% of them remain undiscovered.

settings.heading: The ocean is an important means of transportation
settings.subheading: About 90% of global trade is carried by sea. It’s also an important source of transportation and supports the tourism industry, which is crucial to the global economy and coastal communities in particular.

settings.heading: The ocean is an endless source of beauty, inspiration, and recreation
settings.subheading:
The ocean has been a source of wonder and fascination for centuries. It provides countless opportunities for recreation and accounts for a large portion of global tourism. It’s even inspired some of the world’s greatest art and literature.

Researchers have also discovered that spending time at the beach can actually change our brainwaves and help us feel more relaxed and peaceful (though most of us ocean souls already knew this, without knowing the exact science behind it).

settings.text:
The ocean isn’t as limitless or as immune to human impacts as we once believed. Only recently has science started to understand the devastating effects of human activities on this finite natural resource. 

The combined impacts of climate change, overfishing, pollution, habitat destruction, and other forms of human exploitation continue to threaten our ocean and no area has been left untouched. Let’s explore just a few of these threats together.

settings.heading: Climate change
settings.subheading:
Climate change creates several unique challenges that can impact the long-term future of the ocean, including more frequent severe weather events, rising ocean temperatures, ocean acidification, and rising sea levels.

Climate change is changing the chemistry of the ocean and causing dangerous imbalances that not only impact marine life, but the humans who live near and rely on the ocean to survive.

settings.heading: Overfishing
settings.subheading:
As our global population grows, so does our demand for seafood. Advancements in commercial fishing technology mean humans now have the ability to wipe out entire fish populations in a very short period of time. 

Today, as much as 80% of the world’s fisheries are either overfished or collapsing. It’s estimated that approximately 170 billion pounds of wildlife are removed from the ocean by fishers each year. 

Scientists fear that continuing to fish at our current rate will cause a full-scale collapse of the world’s fisheries—a major threat to global food security.

settings.heading: Plastic pollution
settings.subheading:
Approximately 18 billion pounds of plastic enters the ocean every year. Plastic pollution poses significant ingestion and entanglement risks for wildlife and can introduce toxins into the marine food chain. It also degrades the marine environment, threatens already vulnerable and endangered species, and impacts biodiversity, which is crucial to the ocean’s health. 

Microplastics have also been found in the air we breathe and foods we eat. Researchers estimate that the average person consumes one credit card worth of plastic each week. While scientists are only starting to understand the impact that plastic has on people, they have learned that plastics contain chemicals that can disrupt the human endocrine system and even cause cancer, diabetes, reproductive disorders, and neurological damage in unborn babies and young children.

settings.heading: Chemical and nutrient pollution
settings.subheading:
Chemical and nutrient pollution from industrial and agricultural runoff can harm crucial marine habitats and impact wildlife; common pollutants include pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, oil, detergents, and sewage. Many of these toxins are “forever chemicals” that have already been banned but will persist in our environment indefinitely.

Plastic can both introduce and absorb chemical pollutants from the surrounding environment; in fact, plastic can accumulate toxins in concentrations up to 1 million times greater than surrounding seawater. These toxins can be absorbed into the living tissue of animals that eat plastic and cause significant health impacts. The same is true for humans who consume seafood.

settings.heading: Noise pollution
settings.subheading: Noise pollution from increased boat traffic, activities in the oil and gas industry (like seismology), and military activities (like underwater sonar) can interrupt animals’ normal behavior patterns and drive them away from crucial habitats. Some noises are so loud that they can cause injuries or even be fatal to wildlife.

settings.text: 4ocean is committed to ending the ocean plastic crisis, but we’re not cleaning the ocean so people can have pretty beaches. The clean ocean movement has never been about aesthetics. This movement is about restoring the marine environment so it can sustain life. It’s about creating jobs in communities whose livelihoods and quality of life are heavily impacted by plastic pollution. The jobs we create incentivize local environmental stewardship and provide new opportunities for growth, equality, education, and prosperity. It’s about working with the communities we serve to create cleaner, safer living conditions for millions of people around the world. Every time you shop 4ocean and pull a pound of trash, you make it possible for us to expand our global ocean cleanup operation, empower people in communities impacted by plastic pollution, and advance our mission to end the ocean plastic crisis.

settings.heading: Help us drive positive action for ocean conservation

settings.text: It’s one thing to celebrate World Oceans Day and another to take action to protect the ocean. Here’s a short list of ways to help drive positive action for our one shared ocean.

settings.heading: Have a conversatio
settings.subheading: Take a moment to reflect on your lifestyle and ask whether there’s more you can do to eliminate single-use plastic from your daily life. Talk to friends and family members, too! Encourage them to go plastic free alongside you and work together to support each other on this journey.

settings.heading: Get organized
settings.subheading: If you’re able to do so safely, organize a small cleanup with family and friends in your local neighborhood or join a pre-planned event near you. If that’s not possible, be aware of your surroundings and pick up any trash you see to keep it out of the ocean.

settings.heading: Stay informed
settings.subheading: Spend part of the day searching the internet for resources that can help you go plastic-free and keep you up to date on the ocean plastic crisis. There are countless blogs, newsletters, and email alerts to sign up for. Staying informed will ensure you stay part of the conversation. Only by educating ourselves can we understand this complex issue and take effective action to solve it.

settings.heading: Spread the word
settings.subheading:
People can’t be part of the solution until they’re aware of the problem. Share this page on your favorite social media platforms to help raise awareness about the importance of protecting our one shared ocean. 

Talk about what you’re doing to end your reliance on single-use plastics and encourage others to get involved in the clean ocean movement alongside you. Make sure you tag @4ocean and use #WorldOceansDay2022 to increase the visibility of anything you post!

settings.heading: Support your favorite ocean-friendly organizations
settings.subheading: There are many incredible organizations working hard every single day to protect the ocean and all of the animals that call it home. If you’re able, consider donating time, supplies, or money to support their efforts and advance the clean ocean movement. We’re in this together!

settings.heading: Clean the ocean with every purchase

settings.text: As always, you can rely on 4ocean’s professional, full-time captains and crews to recover harmful marine debris on your behalf. Visit our shop where every product sold funds the removal of one pound of trash from the world’s oceans, rivers, and coastlines.
